coredata.dc:title: Oxygen K-edge XANES of crystalline and amorphous ice
coredata.dc:creator: Tse, J.S.
Tan, K.H.
Chen, J.M.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The oxygen K-edge absorption spectra of crystalline ice Ic and amorphous ice have been measured using monochromatized synchrotron radiation. The differences in the local structure between the crystalline and amorphous phases are clearly reflected in their near edge features. For ice Ic, a surprisingly good correlation was found between the interatomic OH and OO distances with the positions of the post edge absorption peaks employing the multiple scattering model of Bianconi and Natoli. This finding suggests that the scattering from the hydrogen atom may be stronger than previously anticipated. The profiles of the absorption spectra are very similar to that observed in the analogous trigonal and amorphous phases of GeO2.

Tan and J.M. Chen Canadian Synchrotron Radiation Facility, University of Wisconsin, Stoughton, WI 53589, USA Received 2 April 1990; in final form 18 September 1990 The oxygen K-edge absorption spectra of crystalline ice Ic and amorphous ice have been measured using snonochromatizcd synchrotron radiation. The differences in the local structure between the crystalline and amorphous phases are clearly reflected in their near edge features. For ice Ic, a surprisingly good correlation was found between the interatomic O H and O O distances with the positions of the post edge absorption peaks employing the multiple scattering model of Bianconi and Natoli. This finding suggests that the scattering from the hydrogen atom may be stronger than previously anticipated. The profiles of the absorption spectra are very similar to that observed in the analogous trigonal and amorphous phases of Gc02. above threshold is inversely proportional to the sep- aration between an atomic pair R. If the energy is represented by a wave vector k, then in atomic units I, Introduction The general availability of synchrotron radiation has greatly promoted the application of X-ray ab- sorption spectroscopy for probing local structure in matters. The theory for the extended absorption fine structures (EXAFS) is well developed and the tech- nique has proven to be invaluable for the determi- nation of the structures of amorphous materials [1]. More recently, activities have been focused on the understanding of the near edge absorption structures (XANES) [2]. It is shown that the XANES features are sensitive t~ the local symmetry and the type of chemical bonding of the exciting atom and can be useful as fingerprint to distinguish structures [2]. At present, no comprehensive theory is available for the interpretation of the near edge structures. A theoretical model proposed by Bianconi and Natoli [3] perhaps is the most successful. It was suggested that the absorption features above the ionization threshold are due to multiple scatterings of the photoelectron by neighbouring atoms. It can be shown [3] that the energy of the absorption peak ~ Issued as NRCCNo. 31850. To whom correspondence should be addressed. [4], kR = C, (1) where C is a constant and equal to 2x if the phase shift is neglected [4]. In practice, C is treated as an empirical parameter and determined by fitting the experimental data to eq. (1). This important rela- tionship opens an alternative route to the investi- gation of the local structures of materials. This method is particularly attractive for compounds of the first-row elements since the bond lengths are usu- ally short and the energy separation between core levels are small making the measurement of high en- ergy EXAFS difficult. There were some initial suc- cesses in the application of the model. The bond lengths in several transition metal oxides and sulfide minerals were found to correlate well with the K-post edge absorption features [5]. A XANES study of the S L2,3-edge absorption in suffides minerals has shown that all the peaks between 10 and 45 eV above the edge can be assigned with the simple relationship [6] given in eq. (1). Another useful application of XANES is to monitor the structural change in a phase 0009-2614/90/S 03.50 1990 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland) 603 Oxygen K-edge XANES of crystalline and amorphous ice * Volume 174, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LE11PERS 23 November 1990 [16]. The radiation is monochromatized with a Mark IV Grasshopper monochromator using a 900 lines/ mm grating and a slit width of 30 ~tm. The energy resolution was about 4.0 eV at 500 eV. The pho- toabsorption spectra were taken by recording the to- tal electron yield from the sample as a function of photon energy [17]. The reference beam intensity (4) was measured simultaneously with the ab- sorbed radiation using a 90% transmission Cu grid. All measurements were than normalized to 4. The spectra were measured from 10 to 160 K in order to examine the temperature dependence of the near edge features. Due to the high vapour pressure of ice, it is difficult to obtain high quality spectrum above 160 K with the total electron yield detection technique. Absolute energy calibration was made against the known O K shell binding energy (532 eV) of gaseous oxygen [18]. The O is ionization energy in amor- phous ice is 537.4 eV as determined by X-ray photo- electron spectroseopy [19). This energy calibration puts the ionization edge immediately, above the most intense peak observed in the spectrum. The cali- brated spectra show a 10 eV shift to lower energy in comparison with those reported earlier [14]. No de- tail on the energy calibration was given in the pre- vious work and it appears that the absolute energy scale may be in error. In the earlier measurement, the first peak was observed at 541 eV which is above the XPS measured O ls ionization potential. The po- sition of the peak is inconsistent with the gas phase result [20] and the assignment to excitations from the O ls to valence-like antibonding orbitals. 3. Results and discussion 3.1. Oxygen K XANES The oxygen K edge photoabsorption spectra of condensed ice at 10, 80 and 150 K are displayed in fig. 1. The profiles of the lower temperature spectra (10 and 80 K) are very similar to each other and in good accord with a previous measurement for D20 ice at 20 K [141 despite the discrepancy in the ab- solute energy (vide supra). Three bands can be iden- tified from the low temperature spectra. A strong pre- edge peak (A) at 531 eV, abroad band (B) centered around 556 eV and a much weaker band (C) at 587 transition. Recently, pressure-induced phase trans- formations in ct-quartz Ge02 have been studied with Ge K-XANES [7 9]. The differences between the 0e O linkages in the high pressure crystalline and amorphous phases are readily identifiable from their NEXAFS spectra [7], When water vapour is condensed slowly on a cold surface below 80 K, a low-density amorphous (LDA) phase of ice is formed [10]. Heating LDA to about 150 K converts it into crystalline ice Ic [11]. The structures of both the amorphous and crystalline forms are well known. In the cubic form, each water molecule is tetrahedrally hydrogen bonded to the nearest neighbours [12]. In the low-density amor- phous form, the water lattice is a continuous random network of hydrogen bonds with a coordination number close to 4 [13]. However, as evident from the large root-mean-squared variations, the local structure is slightly distorted from the regular tet- rahedron [13]. Therefore, the amor- phous *crystalline phase transformation will pro- vide a stringent test on the applicability of XANES in extracting information on small structural modi- fications. Moreover, the results are the guide to en- suing study of the mechanism of formation of va- pour deposited hydrates. In this paper, the O K XANES spectra on the amorphous and crystalline form of ice are studied and the data analysed with the Natoli Bianconi multiple scattering model [3]. The EXAFS of vapour condensed amorphous ice has been published previously [14]. 2. Experiment Ice samples were prepared by slow condensation of degassed deionized water at a rate of 50 mg/h onto a clean copper plate (t X 1 ) attached to the end of a Displex at 10 K in a vacuum chamber at a pressure of l0~ Ton [10,15]. Care had been taken to ensure no adsorbed oxygen impurities were on the surface of the sample holder. X-ray diffraction on samples prepared under similar conditions confirmed the structure to be that of low-density amorphous ice. The X-ray absorption experiments were performed at the Canadian Synchrotron Radiation Facility (CSRF) situated on the Aladdin 1 0cV electron storage ring operated by the University of Wisconsin 604 Volume 174, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEiTERS 23November 1990 Fig. l.Oxygen K photoabsorption spectra for ice deposited at 10 K. E, at 537.4 eV is the O Is ionization energy for amorphous ice. eV are found. At 150 K where the amorphous crys- talline transformation occurred [11], the basic three band structure is still dominant, but there are subtle differences in detail. A new peak (B ) starts to emerge from the lower energy side (546 eV) of the second band and the higher energy peak has gained some intensity. It is also apparent, as indicated by the dashed line in fig. 1, that the energy of the B peak has increased slightly between 80 and 150 K. 3.2. Correlations of XANES with structure Based on the multiple scattering theory, Natoli has proven that the post edge absorption features can be correlated with interatomic distances [3]. There is now a growing number of empirical observations in support of this interpretation [5,6]. It is of consid- erable interest to analysis to XANES of ice Ic with the multiple scattering model. For practical appli- cations, where the. energy of the absorption peak above the ionization threshold (Ass) is often ex- pressed in eV and the distance R in A, then eq. (1) becomes, Ass 1V = C, (2) where C equals to 150 if the phase shift is neglected [4,5]. Since core ionization is a localized process, to a first approximation, the local environment can be represented by the nearest-neighbour distribution [12]. For crystalline ice the minimum cluster [21] is the (H20 ) supermolecule as shown in fig. 2 (top). The structure of the first coordination shell consists of a central water hydrogen bonded to a tetrahedron of water molecules. The relevant interatomic bond distances which may contribute to the XANES are depicted in fig. 2 (bottom). Contributions from the higher-order coordination shells are expected to be weaker and occur at energy closer to the threshold. The experimental peak positions (Ass) above the ionization threshold for ice Ic obtained from the ex- perimental spectrum at 150 K are 10 (B ), 20 (8) and 55eV (C). A plot of Ass against 1/1V (fig. 3) reveals a linear correlation with a non-zero phase shift. The interatomic distances calculated by sub- stituting the experimental energies into eq. (2) and neglecting the phase shift term are 1.65, 2.81 and 3.84 A. These distances are to be compared with the ac- tual values of 1.745, 2.73 and 3.21 A derived from diffraction experiments [12] and the agreement is satisfactory, On the basis of the multiple scattering model, the post edge peaks B , B and C can then be assigned to scatterings from the O4 Hb , a~ b and OrHb bonds, respectively. / 097M OaC~.__Hb_Ob e- t.754A -~ I.. 2.2 3A Fig. 2. Minimum (H2C))5 cluster model for crystalline ice (top) and the nearest neighbour distances (bottom). 550 575 600 625 650 Photon Energy (ev) 605 Volume 174, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEiTERS 23 November 1990 Fig. 3. A plot of the correlation between LIE and I JR2 for ice Ic. Although the experimental data available for the XANES bond distance correlation is limited, there is additional evidence in favour of this interpreta- tion. The intensity of peak B is stronger than that of B and C. This is to be expected as the scatterings between the oxygen atoms should be greater than that between the oxygen and hydrogen. It is interesting to note the intensity of peak B is not very weakas might anticipated for scattering from a hydrogen atom. It has been observed in an EXAFS experiment that when a hydrogen atom is located between an ab- sorber and a backscatterer, the modulation in the fine structures will be enhanced even though hydrogen shows no measurable backscattering strength [221. There is a weak indication that peak B is shifted by 0.7 eV to higher energy when the temperature is raised from 80 to 150 K (fig. 1). This energy shift corresponds to a contraction of the Q b bond by 0.05 A from the amorphous to the crystalline phase. This observation is in agreement with the results ob- mined from a Raman study of amorphous and ice Ic [23]. Analysis of the band shape of the uncoupled 0H Raman vibrational band suggested that the 0 O distance is reduced from 2.76 A at 120 K for amorphous ice to 2.73Ain ice Ic at 150K [23].The shortening of the O O bond simply reflects stronger hydrogen bonding in ice Ic which is the more stable phase. Adopting the above structural description, it is straightforward to understand the spectra of LDA. In the amorphous state, although the short range or- der is maintained, both the O H bond lengths and the O O O linkages will have a broader distribution and the local environment will no longer be strictly tetrahedral. The root-mean-squared variation of the local O O O angle estimated from neutron scatter- ing is about 80 [13]. The deviation in the a41b distance is 0.1 A and amounts to a spread in Ass of 1 eV. Disorder of a similar magnitude is also ex- pected for the C b and 0, Fib bond distances [13]. This distribution of interatomic distances broaden the absorption peaks and reduce their in- tensities. Consequently, in the experimental spectra of amorphous ice, peak B is no longer visible and peak C has widened relative to that in ice Ic. The spectra for amorphous and crystalline ice share many similarities with those of 0e02 in the corre- sponding states [7 9]. The resemblance in the XANES is no doubt due to the essentially identical local structures of the two materials. Crystalline Ge02 exists in two polymorphic forms. A six-coordinated tetragonal rutile structure and a trigonal a-quartz structure (q-GeO2). In q-Ge02, the t~rystal lattice is composed of linked GeO4 tetrahedra analogous to that in crystalline ice [241. The amorphous form (a- GeO2) is prepared from quenching the melt of GeO2. The most distinctive feature of the Ge K XANES in q-GeO2 is the triple peak structure with the second band splitted into two peaks (B, B ) [8,9]. In a-Ge02 the second (B) and third band (C) are broadened and the splitting in the second peak is only visible under very high instrumental resolution [9]. In previous XANES studies of 0e02 [7 9], no at- tempt was made to correlated structural parameters with the absorption fine structures. In the trigonal structure (q-Ge02), the position of the near edge features B , B and C is 10, 13 and 21 eV above the ionization threshold respectively. Application of eq. (2) gives interatomic distances of 3.90, 3.40 and 2.73 A respectively. These distances can be reasonably correlated to the nearest neighbour Ge Ge distances of 3.90, 3.15 and 2.53 A and Ge O distances of 3.39 and 2.76 A [24]. The good agreement between the predicted and observed interatomic distances fur- ther substantiates the validity of the multiple scat- tering theory and gives credence to the assignments suggested for the ice Ic XANES spectrum. C O o o 0 o. OEDO 0.10 0.20 0.30 0.40 1/B2 (A2) 606 Volume 174, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEiTERS 23 November 1990 3.3. Multiple scattering calculations The most stringent test of the assignment is to cal- culate the XANES spectrum from first principles. The multiple-scattering method [25 27] employing the Xa exchange (MS-Xa) was used, Since core exci- tation is primarily a localized process, the crystalline ice Je structure was approximated by the minimum (H2O)5 cluster (fig. 2). Details of the MS-Xa cal- culations are well documented and will not be elab- orated on here [28] ~. In essence, a self-consistent field calculation was performed on the cluster and the converged potential was used to construct the continuum spectrum. Excitations from the O K shell of the central water molecule were calculated using the formulation described earlier [26,27]. The theoretical XANES spectrum for the (H2O)5 cluster is compared with the ice Ic spectrum in fig. 4. The agreement between the theory and experi- ment is exceedingly good in spite of the simplicity of the model. All the essential features observed in the experimental spectrum are reproduced by the cal- culations. The lowest energy peak (A) is the most intense. Theoretical calculations predict the peak to ~ A C2~ symmetry was assumed in the calculations. The rele- vant parameters are: r(Oj= 1.713, r(H.)=l.118, r(Ob) =1.128, r(Hb)=I.2l0, r,,,1=8.t67 bohr, a0=0.74447, aH =0.77725, a1~,=a,~,e0.75267. be splitted due to different final state symmetries but this splitting is not observed in the experiment due to limited resolution. A hint of a shoulder is ob- served in the better resolved D spectrum reported earlier. The splitting of the second band into B and B is also predicted by the calculation although the energy difference between the two peaks is under- estimated. The intensity of peak C is greatly exag- gerated by the calculation. The overestimation of the intensity of high energy peak is not uncommon for this kind of cluster calculation [29]. It is mainly due to the neglect of the higher-order coordination shells in the calculations. Apart from the discrepancy in the calculated intensities, it is evident that all the main features in the XANES of ice Ic can be described by the minimum cluster model. Therefore, the corre- lation of the near edge structures with that of the nearest neighbour interatomic distance is essentially correct. The O K XANES spectrum projects out the un- occupied p states in ice. Three sets of ls p transi- tions are predicted from the multiple scattering cal- culations which are responsible for the A, B (B ) and C bands. The strong pre-edge peak A, which is also observed in the gas phase [20], can be assigned to the ls-.3p(&~) transition [14]. The higher energy excitations, which are absent in the gas phase, are transitions into Rydberg p states. The (repulsive) interactions between the diffuse Rydberg orbital with the neighbouring molecules in the condensed phase localize (renormalize) the orbital within the molec- ular core and increases the oscillator strength for the transition. These kind of interactions have been ob- served in simple molecules, such as SF5 [30] and TeF6 [31] and are analogous to the more familiar shape resonance [32] phenomenon, Moreover, the localization of the Rydberg orbitals is dependent on ~ the local symmetry and the separation between mol- b ecules, and this forms the theoretical basis for the interatomic distance absorption energy correlation. A theoretical study of the correlation of molecular valence and K shell photoionization resonances with bond lengths has been published recently [33]. 615 n O = p 2 ~ ~0 C O o n 1, o n Fig. 4. Phys. 91(1989)1796. vapour deposited at 10 K have been measured as a function of temperature. The amorphoes crys- talline phase transition at 150 K is readily charac- terized from the differences in the post edge absorp- tion fine structures. The present results strongly sug- gested that XANES is a very sensitive technique to monitor small structural changes. The absorption spectrum of ice Ic shows a three band structure. This profile is typical of crystalline structure with a tetra- hedral local environment. The post edge features were found to correlate very well with the interatomic dis- tances from the nearest neighbours as predicted by the multiple scattering model of Bianconi and Natoli and first principle MS-Xcr calculations. The broad- ening of the XANES features in the amorphous phase is characteristic of a glass and is due to the increased disordered in the O O O angles. References [1] D.C. Koningsberger and R. head.ce:title: Oxygen K-edge XANES of crystalline and amorphous ice

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The oxygen K-edge absorption spectra of crystalline ice Ic and amorphous ice have been measured using monochromatized synchrotron radiation. The differences in the local structure between the crystalline and amorphous phases are clearly reflected in their near edge features. For ice Ic, a surprisingly good correlation was found between the interatomic OH and OO distances with the positions of the post edge absorption peaks employing the multiple scattering model of Bianconi and Natoli. This finding suggests that the scattering from the hydrogen atom may be stronger than previously anticipated. The profiles of the absorption spectra are very similar to that observed in the analogous trigonal and amorphous phases of GeO2.

X-ray absorption - principles, applications, techniques of EXAFS, SEXAFS and XANES
